text: I'm Dr Larry alel I am head of

about genes involved in Alzheimer's
disease apoe AP PS1 and PS2 recently
other genes have been discovered to be
associated with Alzheimer's disease can
you tell us what this has taught us
about the pathology of AD and what it
might mean for
treatment in addition to AP prein one
and apoe4 there are a number of of genes
that have been associated with
increasing the risk uh for Alzheimer's
disease they seem however to
be uh effects that you can only detect
when you look at an enormous population
and so far we can't reduce those to like
mutations that we can test for in an
individual person so for AP and PS1 and
PS2 and ae4 we know exactly where to
look in the gene to see where the
mistakes might be that cause Alzheimer's
disease for genes like soral one which
is one of the genes or clusterin um we
don't know exactly where to look we
can't we can't we don't have the
Precision to know where to do how to do
a test that will uh reduce that to an
individual risk we can only look at that
at the population
level what also these studies may tell
us is that Alzheimer disease is not caus
by a single defect there be many you
know many factors many uh Gene
abnormalities that you know in concert
contribute to the development of the
disease and it's not going to be just a
single you know a single Gene it doesn't
have to be a gen I mean genes could be
important but doesn't have to be a gene
abnormal it's not all about genes it's
uh there is this part also of science
which is called AP genetic which means
it's not the gene the Chang or the
combination of genes but could be
factors that are external to the gene
that affect in a different way the genes
so it's we need to keep our mind open
broad mentality on all what we do on
these things without focusing excess it
is important but it's not the only part
of this story yeah I think the question
uh really prompts a broader question and
that is as genomic technology uh gets
more and more powerful and we can
identify genes that have tiny effects
for this disease or that disease uh and
we need large large populations of
people to see these tiny effects what do
we do with that information is that is
that actionable uh and uh I think we we
still don't know none of us know uh
where this is heading and how we're
going to harness this uh genomics
technology in in terms of what these
rarer genes or more genes that we've
discovered in populations have told us
about the pathology for everyone that's
been tested they seem to dovetail into
what we call the ameloid hypothesis all
of these genes whenever you turn them
down in a mouse model they make the
amalo build up worse so they all have so
far reinforced the the amalo model of
how the disease begins um we don't know
exactly how that's how that relates to
all forms of of common disease but these
genetic risk factors whenever we've
identified them all seem to it's
possible to fit them into the sort of a
unifying picture of of the
pathology
